title: Crocker Range
text:
Crocker Range () is a <a href="mountain%20range">mountain range</a> in <a href="West%20Coast%20Division">West Coast Division</a> of <a href="Sabah">Sabah</a>, <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> that separates the west and east coast of Sabah. At an average height of , it is the highest mountain range in the state with the range is named after the British administrator in <a href="North%20Borneo">North Borneo</a>, <a href="William%20Maunder%20Crocker">William Maunder Crocker</a>.
Geology.
The range is made up of uplifted and folded <a href="sedimentary%20rock">sedimentary rock</a>s consisted of weathered soft <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a>s and <a href="shale">shale</a>s. The highest point is <a href="Mount%20Kinabalu">Mount Kinabalu</a> at . Most of the park boundary lies above with its lowlands used for <a href="cash%20crop">cash crop</a>s and <a href="paddy%20field">paddy field</a>. On the east of the range located the Tambunan Valley at which are mainly <a href="terrace%20%28agriculture%29">terraced</a> paddy fields and groves of <a href="bamboo">bamboo</a>s border the north-eastern part of the protected park. The park area is important as a <a href="water%20catchment">water catchment</a> to supply water into various river in the west coast and interior districts of Sabah including <a href="Papar%20River">Papar River</a>, Kimanis River, Bongawan River, Membakut River, <a href="Padas%20River">Padas River</a> and Melalap River that flow west to the park while the Pegalan River, Pampang River, Apin-Apin River, Tendulu River, Melalap River, Liawan River and Tikalod River flow the opposite direction.
History.
The area surrounding <a href="Mount%20Kinabalu">Mount Kinabalu</a> has been a state park since 1964 and was the country's first <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a>. Part of the range has been gazetted for protection as <a href="Crocker%20Range%20National%20Park">Crocker Range National Park</a> since 1984. Through the Bornean Biodiversity and Ecosystems Conservation Programme (BBEC), a technical co-operation existed between the <a href="government%20of%20Sabah">government of Sabah</a> and <a href="Japan%20International%20Cooperation%20Agency">Japan International Cooperation Agency</a> (JICA) to innovate Community Use Zone (CUZ) concept as a management option to address the issues concerning indigenous communities living and utilising resources within the protected areas. Mount Kinabalu, one of the highest mountains in <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, is part of this range. In 2014, the mountain range was recognised as a <a href="UNESCO%20Biosphere%20Reserve">UNESCO Biosphere Reserve</a>, becoming the second Malaysian site thus designated, after <a href="Chini%20Lake">Chini Lake</a> in the <a href="Malay%20Peninsula">Malay Peninsula</a> of <a href="Pahang">Pahang</a>.
Biodiversity.
The Crocker Range Forest Reserve area has a wide ranges of <a href="flora">flora</a> and <a href="fauna">fauna</a> diversity and having the highest diversity of <a href="nocturnality">nocturnal</a> insects in all the 20 forest reserves surveyed within the <a href="Heart%20of%20Borneo">Heart of Borneo</a> area in Sabah and recorded a number of endemic species.
